title: Sarah Farnsworth Hatch
text:
Hello! I am a third-year PhD student at Harvard Graduate School of Education.
I study what we can do (programs, interventions) to help kids thrive, especially before they start to experience social, emotional, academic, or behavioral problems. I am trained by applied developmental psychologists with a focus on prevention and implementation science.
Before my doctoral program, I worked as an education specialist at the University of Pennsylvania’s Implementation Science Center. I received a MSEd from the University of Pennsylvania’s Graduate School of Education and a BS in Sociology from Brigham Young University.
Check out my projects tab to see what I’m currently working on, or download my CV for my most recent academic publications.

title: Ongoing Projects
text: I am a primary investigator on several projects, with incredible mentors and peers providing critical feedback and partnership along the way. I am also an active contributor in Stephanie Jones’ EASEL lab and Dana McCoy’s SEED lab. I am particularly drawn to “getting under the hood” of why people behave the ways they do when implementing or influencing children’s education, particularly education which supports children’s social and emotional learning (SEL).

title: Contact Me subtitle: Email
links: - icon: envelope text: Email url: mailto:shatch@g.harvard.edu

title: Ongoing Projects
text:
With Stephanie Jones (EASEL Lab)

Analyzing implementation data and impacts from an RCT on SEL in after-school settings in Nebraska.
Analyzing implementation data from the national rollout of a trauma-informed, locally adapted SEL curriculum in Ukraine.

title: Ongoing Projects
text:
With Dana McCoy (SEED Lab)

Analyzing implementation of an AI-based parenting app in Peru, which showed positive effects on children’s development.
Examining mechanisms connecting the app to these positive outcomes.
Investigating associations between specific parenting behaviors and children’s behavioral outcomes in this context.

title: Ongoing Projects
section: Parents’ Politicized Views of Education in the US
text:
Parents’ Politicized Views of Education in the US

Qualitative study examining conservative parents’ views of SEL (manuscript in preparation).
Conjoint survey on Democrat and Republican SEL preferences.

title: Ongoing Projects
text:
School Censorship Studies

Predicting school censorship behaviors using a mix of classic and novel political science and social psychology measures.
Novel scales looking at parents’ beliefs surrounding “psychological fragility” and “conversational self-efficacy” using advanced psychometric approaches.

title: Ongoing Projects
section: Parents’ Politicized Educational Views and Behaviors
text:
Parents’ Politicized Educational Views and Behaviors

Conservative views of SEL: I utilize relational interviews in my home community to examine variation behind parents’ views of SEL.
Predicting school censorship: I use an experimental paradigm and original data to examine predictors of parents’ school censorship behaviors, using a mix of classic and novel political science and social psychology measures.
Parenting beliefs and censorship: using Item Response Theory, I develop and test the validity evidence of two new measures of parenting beliefs which may predict parents’ censorship behaviors.
SEL opposition experiment: I use conjoint survey methods to explore differences in Republican and Democrat parents’ SEL-related preferences.
